questions.prompt: If H is a subgroup of G and a ∈ G, the left coset aH is:
questions.explanation: The left coset of H containing a is aH = {ah : h ∈ H}. Similarly, the right coset is Ha = {ha : h ∈ H}.

questions.prompt: Two left cosets aH and bH are equal if and only if:
questions.explanation: aH = bH if and only if a⁻¹b ∈ H (equivalently, b ∈ aH). This is a fundamental property of cosets.

questions.prompt: In the group Z under addition, what are the cosets of the subgroup 3Z = {..., -3, 0, 3, 6, ...}?
questions.explanation: The cosets of 3Z in Z are: 0+3Z = 3Z = {...,-3,0,3,6,...}, 1+3Z = {...,-2,1,4,7,...}, and 2+3Z = {...,-1,2,5,8,...}. These three cosets partition Z.

questions.prompt: All cosets of a subgroup H in G have:
questions.explanation: Every coset of H has exactly |H| elements. The map h ↦ ah is a bijection from H to aH.

questions.prompt: The set of all left cosets of H in G forms:
questions.explanation: The left cosets of H partition G: every element of G is in exactly one left coset. However, they don't always form a group under coset multiplication (only when H is normal).

title: Cosets and Lagrange's Theorem - Lagrange's Theorem

questions.prompt: Lagrange's Theorem states that if H is a subgroup of a finite group G, then:
questions.explanation: Lagrange's Theorem: If G is a finite group and H ≤ G, then |H| divides |G|. Moreover, |G| = |H| · [G:H], where [G:H] is the index (number of cosets).

questions.prompt: If G is a group of order 35, what are the possible orders of subgroups of G?
questions.explanation: By Lagrange's Theorem, subgroup orders must divide |G| = 35 = 5·7. The divisors of 35 are 1, 5, 7, and 35.

questions.prompt: If G is a finite group and a ∈ G, then the order of a:
questions.explanation: The order of element a equals the order of the cyclic subgroup ⟨a⟩. By Lagrange's Theorem, |⟨a⟩| divides |G|, so |a| divides |G|.

questions.prompt: If G is a group of order 17, then G must be:
questions.explanation: If |G| = p where p is prime, then G is cyclic (and isomorphic to Zₚ). Any non-identity element generates the entire group.

questions.prompt: The index [G:H] of a subgroup H in G is:
options: The number of distinct left (or right) cosets of H in G
The number of elements in H
questions.explanation: The index [G:H] is the number of distinct left cosets of H in G. By Lagrange's Theorem, [G:H] = |G|/|H|.

title: Cosets and Lagrange's Theorem - Normal Subgroups and Quotients

questions.prompt: A subgroup H of G is normal (H ⊴ G) if:
options: gH = Hg for all g ∈ G
questions.explanation: H is normal in G if the left and right cosets coincide for all g ∈ G. Equivalently, gHg⁻¹ = H for all g ∈ G.

questions.prompt: In an abelian group G, every subgroup H is:
questions.explanation: In an abelian group, gH = Hg for all g and H, since gh = hg for all elements. Thus every subgroup is normal.

questions.prompt: If H is a normal subgroup of G, the quotient group G/H consists of:
options: Elements of G not in H
Elements of G that commute with H
The set of all cosets of H with operation (aH)(bH) = abH
questions.explanation: When H ⊴ G, the set of cosets G/H = {aH : a ∈ G} forms a group under coset multiplication (aH)(bH) = abH.

questions.prompt: If |G| = 30 and H is a subgroup of order 15, is H necessarily normal in G?
options: No, H cannot exist by Lagrange's Theorem
No, normality depends on more than just the order
questions.explanation: Any subgroup of index 2 is normal. Here [G:H] = 30/15 = 2, so H ⊴ G.

questions.prompt: What is the order of the quotient group Z₁₂/⟨4⟩?
